data.title: Keyboard Cipher
data.solution:
keyboard = ["`1234567890-=", "qwertyuiop[]\\",
  "asdfghjkl;'", "zxcvbnm,./", " "]
n = gets.to_i
line = gets.chomp
coordinates = line.split.map{|i| 
  row_number, index = i.chars.map(&:hex)
 }
decrypted_letters = coordinates.map{|i, j| 
  row = keyboard[i]
  row[j]
 }
puts decrypted_letters.join

testCases.title: Validator 3
testCases.testOut: 3250a-wa0[];fd'.,/';' isn't a hidden message; it's nonsense

testCases.title: Test 4
testCases.testOut: 1.61803398875...=the golden ratio - aka one point six one eight oh three three nine and 2 fat ladies [7\5] the golden ratio; tyrannicide

data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loopline n keyboardCoordinates:word(2)
write Decrypted message

STATEMENT
Decrypt it!
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1 :>> an integer [[n]]
<<Line 2 :>> [[n]] space-separated hexadecimal [[keyboard_coordinates]], the two characters representing the row and index of each character on a QWERTY keyboard, respectively
data.outputDescription: <<1 Line :>> an [[n]]-character string represented the decrypted message

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You've received a message encrypted by a simple cipher. Each character has been encrypted based on which QWERTY keyboard row and index it appears at, represented as a 2-character hexadecimal number.

The rows of a QWERTY keyboard are:
Row 0: `1234567890-=
Row 1: qwertyuiop[]\
Row 2: asdfghjkl;'
Row 3: zxcvbnm,./

So, the character s is represented as 21 in this representation since it occurs in row 2 and index 1 (both 0-indexed). A "[" is represented as 1a (a is 10 in hexadecimal). A space (" ") is represented as 40.

Given an integer n and then n space-separated hexadecimal keyboard_coordinates, print the decrypted message, all in lowercase/unshifted characters.
Input
Line 1 : an integer n
Line 2 : n space-separated hexadecimal keyboard_coordinates, the two characters representing the row and index of each character on a QWERTY keyboard, respectively
Output
1 Line : an n-character string represented the decrypted message
Constraints
1 < n < 200
All input will have a valid solution.
Outputs will all be lowercase/unshifted characters.
No newlines in output.
Example
Input
6
10 11 12 13 14 15
Output
qwerty
